message_1:
Here's a numerical problem related to Paraconsistent logic: 

Suppose that P and Q are two propositions, and we know that P is true and Q is false. Using Paraconsistent logic, determine the truth value of the following propositions: 

1. P and Q
2. P or Q
3. ~(P and Q)
message_2:
Using Paraconsistent logic, we can determine the truth values of the given propositions as follows:

1. P and Q: In Paraconsistent logic, if one proposition is true and the other is false, the conjunction (P and Q) is considered false. So, the truth value of P and Q is false.

2. P or Q: In Paraconsistent logic, the disjunction (P or Q) is true if at least one of the propositions is true. Since P is true, the truth value of P or Q is true.

3. ~(P and Q): The negation of a proposition in Paraconsistent logic is true if the original proposition is false. Since P and Q is false, the truth value of ~(P and Q) is true.
